byline.contributor: Al Baker, Matt Flegenheimer and Benjamin Mueller contributed reporting.
byline.original: By PATRICK McGEEHAN and JIHA HAM

abstract: Consolidated Edison and owners of restaurant in building destroyed in East Village gas explosion report that utility workers had discovered gas was being illegally siphoned in dangerous way at location over seven months before explosion; discovery caused Con Edison to shut off all gas to the building for 10 days in August while repairs were made.
lead_paragraph: Con Edison workers were called to 121 Second Avenue in August for a “strong odor” of gas, and found multiple leaks in hoses that had been connected to the line, creating a “hazardous situation.”

headline.main: Months Before East Village Blast, Utility Found Gas Line Was Tapped in Dangerous Way
headline.print_headline: Months Before Blast, Utility Found Gas Line Was Tapped in Dangerous Way

snippet: Con Edison workers were called to 121 Second Avenue in August for a “strong odor” of gas, and found multiple leaks in hoses that had been connected to the line, creating a “hazardous situation.”
